STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 4, 2021
Timothy Click
Barry County DHHS
430 Barfield Drive
Hastings, MI 49058
RE: License #: CP080200963
Barry County DHHS
430 Barfield Drive
Hastings, MI 49058
Dear Mr. Click:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on April 26 –
April 30, 2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of policy and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of policy or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)-204-6992.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

Services

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One of six open foster care files reviewed contained an initial service plan that was
completed outside of the 30-day timeframe.
This is a repeat violation cited in the following:
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/30/2019, CAP approved on 6/28/2019
Renewal Inspection Report dated 5/6/2020, CAP approved 5/21/2020
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
One of six open foster care files reviewed contained a documented monthly foster
home visit with a youth during which the foster parent was not present.
This is a repeat violation cited in the following:
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/30/2019, CAP approved on 6/28/2019
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
4

FOM 801 Medical Passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
Quarterly.
At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
Medical Passport Receipt Documentation
Receipt of the medical passport by the required parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
Five of six open foster care files reviewed did not have all of the required medical
passport receipt documentation.
This is a repeat violation cited in the following:
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/30/2019, CAP approved on 6/28/2019
Renewal Inspection Report dated 5/6/2020, CAP approved 5/21/2020
FOM 722.03 Placement exception request (PER)
PER must be completed when required and completed
quarterly.
One of six open foster care files reviewed contained PER’s that were not completed
timely.
This is a repeat violation cited in the following:
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/30/2019, CAP approved on 6/28/2019
Renewal Inspection Report dated 5/6/2020, CAP approved 5/21/2020
FOM 722-09C FOSTER CARE ACTION SUMMARY REQUIREMENTS
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
One of six open foster care case files reviewed did not contain Action Summaries
completed as required for placement changes
Two of two closed foster care cases reviewed did not contain the required action
summaries.
5

This is a repeat violation cited in the following:
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/30/2019, CAP approved on 6/28/2019
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
Caregiver
The individual activities required by the foster
parent/caregiver to meet the specific individual needs of
the child placed in their home are included in the PATP.
The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP
process. The foster parent/caregiver signature is required
and indicates that the foster parent/caregiver
acknowledges and agrees to the activities required to meet
the needs of the child in their care. Additionally, the PATP
details the services and activities provided by the foster
care worker to assist the foster parent/caregiver in caring
for the child.
Two of six open foster care case files reviewed did not contain all signatures, as
required.
This is a repeat violation cited in the following:
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/30/2019, CAP approved on 6/28/2019
FOM 722-08C Required Participation in Development - Parents and Youth
over 14-Years Old
Upon completion of the parent-agency treatment plan and
service agreement, the parent is given a copy for review.
Foster care workers need to ensure the parent understands
all areas within the agreement. Parents and youths age 14
and older must sign the PATP. If a parent or youth is
unavailable or refuses to sign the PATP, foster care
workers must identify and document additional action
needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s participation
in service planning and compliance with the PATP. As the
goals are achieved, modified or expanded, the updated
PATP will reflect this process. Parents and youths age 14
and older must participate in the development of each
updated treatment plan, allowing for opportunity to
evaluate their progress towards completing goals.
Three of six open foster care case files reviewed were missing required signatures
on the PATP’s.
This is a repeat violation cited in the following:
6

Interim Inspection Report dated 5/30/2019, CAP approved on 6/28/2019
722-06B Family Team Meeting
The Family Team Meeting (FTM) is an essential component
of MiTEAM, Michigan’s Child Welfare Practice Model. FTMs
serve as the primary forum for safety planning,
collaborative service planning, service identification, and
assessing progress. The FTM represents a child-centered,
family-driven, strength-based, team-guided approach,
designed to engage families in developing plans for the
safety, permanency and well-being of their children and
family.
Three of six open foster care case files reviewed were missing required FTM’s
This is a repeat violation cited in the following:
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/30/2019, CAP approved on 6/28/2019
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Linking FTM’s to applicable service plans
Documenting efforts to engage family in service planning in lieu of signatures
V. CONSULTATION
No consultation was required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted no acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
Despite all of the violations in this inspection being repeat violations there have been
a reduction of the number of files affected throughout the years. Additionally, the
violation found in this inspection were primarily related to staffing concerns as well
as issues with properly documenting efforts made to secure documentation during
the pandemic.
CHIEF ADMINISTRATOR ASSESSMENT
The Chief Administrator indicated that the CAP developed after the 2020 inspection
was primarily successful, but there were some areas in which a few errors were
7

made. Additionally, there was a staff member undergoing disciplinary action for a
period of time during which the casework being completed was inadequate. The only
other issues identified were concerning difficulty meeting deadlines, primarily for
medical and dental appointments, due to limitations presented by the pandemic.
This was reflected in the files reviewed.
STAFF INTERVIEWS
The staff interviewed reported no concerns other than the difficulty in managing
cases assigned from other staff members’ caseloads who have either left the agency
and/or who have repeatedly gone on leave.
CHRI
I viewed the CHRI information stored in a secure location on 4/27/2021 via Microsoft
Teams.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on
a regular license.
5/03/2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 3, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
